title: Dreyfus denial not fooling us
text:
Labor frontbencher Mark Dreyfus rubbished our prediction on Monday that he would soon quit federal parliament for an appointment to Victoria’s judiciary. “Despite reheating of baseless rumours this morning, as I said in August I’ll be staying and fighting the next election.” So what? He’d previously given the suggestion short shrift when asked in August by The Age’s Rob Harris. “I don’t know where these ridiculous suggestions come from.” The indignance!

Funnily enough, they probably come from the high-level discussions Dreyfus has held on Spring Street with everyone from Premier Daniel Andrews, former Attorney-General Martin Pakula, his successor Jill Hennessy and his caucus colleagues. Or from his threats to quit parliament in October 2018, or his indiscreet utterances around the traps.

Predictably, his unfaithful denial was enough for the Twittersphere – especially former Crikey gossip Stephen Mayne, who managed to see this through the prism of his own running, provincial feud with 1990s blog rival Andrew Landeryou (and by extension his wife, Labor Senator Kimberley Kitching). Yawn. We certainly don’t need anyone else to tell us what we think of the learned member for Isaacs.

We won’t easily forget the torrential scorn we copped in September 2016 when we wrote that George Brandis would replace Alexander Downer as High Commissioner in London. Brandis renounced our tale, Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull refuted it, Foreign Minister Julie Bishop categorically denied it and so did the government: “George Brandis is not going to London. George is not under consideration,” a source said. And where’s George now?

One thing’s for sure, though: Dreyfus will not be replacing Justice Chris Maxwell as President of Victoria’s Court of Appeal. Contrary to speculation (ours included), Maxwell does not intend to step down before his mandatory retirement date in January 2023, his 70th birthday. Nevertheless, there are a multitude of routes onto the Supreme Court bench for Dreyfus before the next Victorian and federal elections in 2022. At 63 himself, Dreyfus hasn’t got much longer than that.
description: Mark Dreyfus has denied he'll quit parliament for an appointment to Victoria's Supreme Court. But George Brandis denied he'd go to London.
